prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Galaxies in a group- P6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: First pointing towards galaxies situated in a group environment. This science goal should allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of two galaxies situated within 3" of the ALMA phase center (increase by only 5% of the effective noise).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The first baseband is centered at the sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line at a redshift of 0.7267, i.e., F_sky=461.04077/(1+0.7267). This baseband, with its large bandwidth (TDM), will allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of our two targets, z_1=0.7262 and z_2=0.7272 The spectral resolution delivered by the TDM mode is sufficient to spectroscopically resolved their expected line width (~300 km/s; Tacconi et al. 2013), while keeping the data rate low.
To allow for the continuum detection of our targets, we have complemented this setup with 2 TDM basebands positioned to cover the rest of the upper sideband.

As the objective of this proposal is the measurement of the total molecular gas content, angular resolution is not critical and most compact configuration is required (i.e., resolution of 1.3"). Our targets are resolved in the optical and have largest angular scales of <1.5".
The position of our pointing has been defined to ensure that our two targets are situated as close as possible to the phase center where the sensitivity is optimal. Our two targets are situated 3" away from the phase center, i.e., at positions where the effective noise increases by only ~5% with respect to that requested.

To measure the expect CO(4-3) line flux densities of the two targets situated in our pointing, we use their infrared luminosities (i.e., LIR; derived from MIPS/PACS detections) and assume a LIR/LCO(1-0) ratio of 60 for "normal" galaxies (Genzel et al. 2010 and Daddi et al. 2010), a LCO(4-3)/LCO(1-0) line ratio of 0.4 for "normal" galaxies (Daddi et al. 2014) and a typical CO line width of 300km/s (Tacconi et al. 2013). This leads to line peak fluxes densities of 1.25 and 2.52 mJy for our two targets.
In the less likely case where our galaxies are in a "starbursting" mode, these line peak flux density estimates would remain unchanged because "normal" and "starbursting" galaxies seems to have the same LCO(J,J-1)/LIR ratio at high-J transitions (J>4; Daddi et al. 2014).
Our targets are positioned within 3" from the phase center of our pointing. At this position the noise increases by only ~5%. Therefore, the resquested rms of 0.25 mJy per 75km/s will provide us with S/N>5 line peak detections and S/N>10 velocity-integrated line detections (4 channels per line width) of our two targets.
Finally, even though it is not our primary scientific goal, the achieved rms over the aggregate bandwidth will allow us to obtain S/N>3 continuum detections of our two targets, as predicted using their (z, LIR, M*) and results from Magnelli et al (2014).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Galaxies in a group- P7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Second pointing towards galaxies situated in a group environment. This science goal should allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of four galaxies situated within 6.5" of the ALMA phase center (increase by 28% of the effective noise).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The first baseband is centered at the sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line at a redshift of 0.7237, i.e., F_sky=461.04077/(1+0.7237). This baseband, with its large bandwidth (TDM), will allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of two of our targets, z_1=0.7234 and z_2=0.7241 The second baseband is centered at the sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line at a redshift of 0.7267, i.e., F_sky=461.04077/(1+0.7267). This baseband, with its large bandwidth (TDM), will allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of the remaining two targets, z_3=0.7257 and z_2=0.7277 The spectral resolution delivered by the TDM mode is sufficient to spectroscopically resolved their expected line width (~300 km/s; Tacconi et al. 2013), while keeping the data rate low.
To allow for the continuum detection of our targets, we have complemented this setup with 2 TDM basebands positioned to cover the rest of the upper sideband.

As the objective of this proposal is the measurement of the total molecular gas content, angular resolution is not critical and most compact configuration is required (i.e., resolution of 1.3"). Our targets are resolved in the optical and have largest angular scales of <1.5".
The position of our pointing has been defined to ensure that our four targets are situated as close as possible to the phase center where the sensitivity is optimal. However, even with this careful optimization, some of our targets are situated 6.5" away from the phase center, i.e., at a position where the effective noise increases by ~28% with respect to that requested. This limitation was taken into account for our sensitivity calculation.

To measure the expect CO(4-3) line flux densities of the four targets situated in our pointing, we use their infrared luminosities (i.e., LIR; derived from MIPS/PACS detections) and assume a LIR/LCO(1-0) ratio of 60 for "normal" galaxies (Genzel et al. 2010 and Daddi et al. 2010), a LCO(4-3)/LCO(1-0) line ratio of 0.4 for "normal" galaxies (Daddi et al. 2014) and a typical CO line width of 300km/s (Tacconi et al. 2013). This leads to line peak fluxes densities of 1.10, 1.27, 2.0 and 3.17 mJy for our four targets.
In the less likely case where our galaxies are in a "starbursting" mode, these line peak flux density estimates would remain unchanged because "normal" and "starbursting" galaxies seems to have the same LCO(J,J-1)/LIR ratio at high-J transitions (J>4; Daddi et al. 2014).
Our targets are positioned within 6.5" from the phase center of our pointing. At this position the noise increases by ~28% and the resquested rms of 0.17 mJy per 75km/s will thus correspond to an effective rms of 0.22 mJy per 75 km/s. This will still provide us with S/N>5 line peak detections and S/N>10 velocity-integrated line detections (4 channels per line width) of our four targets.
Finally, even though it is not our primary scientific goal, the achieved rms over the aggregate bandwidth will allow us to obtain S/N>8 continuum detections of our four targets, as predicted using their (z, LIR, M*) and results from Magnelli et al (2014).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Galaxies in a group - P8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Third pointing towards galaxies situated in a group environment. This science goal should allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of one galaxy situated at the ALMA phase center.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The first baseband is centered at the sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line at the redshift of our target, i.e., F_sky=461.04077/(1+0.7257). The spectral resolution delivered by the TDM mode is not sufficient to spectroscopically resolved their expected line width (~300 km/s; Tacconi et al. 2013), while keeping the data rate low.
To allow for the continuum detection of our targets, we have complemented this setup with 2 TDM basebands positioned to cover the rest of the upper sideband.

As the objective of this proposal is the measurement of the total molecular gas content, angular resolution is not critical and most compact configuration is required (i.e., resolution of 1.3"). Our targets is resolved in the optical and has largest angular scale of <1.5".

To measure the expect CO(4-3) line flux density of our target, we use its infrared luminosity (i.e., LIR; derived from MIPS/PACS detections) and assume a LIR/LCO(1-0) ratio of 60 for "normal" galaxies (Genzel et al. 2010 and Daddi et al. 2010), a LCO(4-3)/LCO(1-0) line ratio of 0.4 for "normal" galaxies (Daddi et al. 2014) and a typical CO line width of 300km/s (Tacconi et al. 2013). This leads to line peak flux density of 7.98 mJy.
In the case where this galaxy is in a "starbursting" mode, this line peak flux density estimate would remain unchanged because "normal" and "starbursting" galaxies seem to have the same LCO(J,J-1)/LIR ratio at high-J transitions (J>4; Daddi et al. 2014).
The resquested rms of 0.8 mJy per 35km/s will provide us with S/N~10 line peak detection and S/N~30 velocity-integrated line detection (8 channels per line width) of our target. Such high detection significance will allow detail study of the line width of this galaxy and subsequently its dynamic.
Finally, even though it is not our primary scientific goal, the achieved rms over the aggregate bandwidth will allow us to obtain S/N~8 continuum detections of our target, as predicted using its (z, LIR, M*) and results from Magnelli et al (2014).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Galaxies in a cluster - P1 - P2 - P4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal contains three pointings toward galaxies situated in a cluster environment. This science goal should allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of five galaxies.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The first baseband is centered at the sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line at a redshift of 0.7327, i.e., F_sky=461.04077/(1+0.7327). This baseband, with its large bandwidth (TDM), will allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of the two targets situated in P1, z_1=0.7324 and z_2=0.7331 The second baseband is centered at the sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line at a redshift of 0.7276, i.e., F_sky=461.04077/(1+0.7276). This baseband, with its large bandwidth (TDM), will allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of one target in P2 and one target in P4, z_3=0.7264 and z_2=0.7289 The third baseband is centered at the sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line at the redshift of the remaining target of P2, i.e., F_sky=461.04077/(1+0.7382).
The spectral resolution delivered by the TDM mode is sufficient to spectroscopically resolved their expected line width (~300 km/s; Tacconi et al. 2013), while keeping the data rate low.
To allow for the continuum detection of our targets, we have complemented this setup with 1 TDM baseband positioned to cover the rest of the upper sideband.

As the objective of this proposal is the measurement of the total molecular gas content, angular resolution is not critical and most compact configuration is required (i.e., resolution of 1.3"). Our targets are well resolved in the optical and have largest angular scales of <1.5".
The position of our pointings have been defined to ensure that our faintest targets are situated as close as possible to the phase center, where the sensitivity is optimal. This position-dependent noise was taken into account for our sensitivity calculation.

To measure the expect CO(4-3) line flux densities of our targets, we use their infrared luminosities (i.e., LIR; derived from MIPS/PACS detections) and assume a LIR/LCO(1-0) ratio of 60 for "normal" galaxies (Genzel et al. 2010 and Daddi et al. 2010), a LCO(4-3)/LCO(1-0) line ratio of 0.4 for "normal" galaxies (Daddi et al. 2014) and a typical CO line width of 300km/s (Tacconi et al. 2013). For P1, this leads to line peak fluxes densities of 1.24 and 1.56 mJy for our two targets. For P2, this leads to line peak fluxes densities of 1.00 and 1.59 mJy for our two targets. For P4, this leads to line peak fluxes densities of 1.02 for our target.
In the less likely case where our galaxies are in a "starbursting" mode, these line peak flux density estimates would remain unchanged because "normal" and "starbursting" galaxies seems to have the same LCO(J,J-1)/LIR ratio at high-J transitions (J>4; Daddi et al. 2014).
In P1, our targets are positioned within 4.0" from the phase center of our pointing. At this position the noise increases by ~10% and the resquested rms of 0.20 mJy per 75km/s will thus correspond to an effective rms of 0.22 mJy per 75 km/s. This will still provide us with S/N>5 line peak detections and S/N>10 velocity-integrated line detections (4 channels per line width) of our two targets.
In P2, our targets are positioned within 2.0" from the phase center of our pointing. At this position the noise increases by only ~3%. The resquested rms of 0.20 mJy per 75km/s will provide us with S/N>5 line peak detections and S/N>10 velocity-integrated line detections (4 channels per line width) of our two targets.
In P4, our target is positioned at the phase center of our pointing. The resquested rms of 0.20 mJy per 75km/s will provide us with a S/N~5 line peak detection and a S/N~10 velocity-integrated line detection (4 channels per line width) of our target.
Finally, even though it is not our primary scientific goal, the achieved rms over the aggregate bandwidth will allow us to obtain S/N>3 continuum detections of our targets, as predicted using their (z, LIR, M*) and results from Magnelli et al (2014).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Galaxies in a cluster - P3 - P5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal contains two pointings toward galaxies situated in a cluster environment. This science goal should allow us to detect the CO(4-3) line of two galaxies.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The first baseband is centered at the sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line at the redshift of our target situated in P3, i.e., F_sky=461.04077/(1+0.7219). The second baseband is centered at the sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line at the redshift of our target situated in P5, i.e., F_sky=461.04077/(1+0.7270).
The spectral resolution delivered by the TDM mode is sufficient to spectroscopically resolved their expected line width (~300 km/s; Tacconi et al. 2013), while keeping the data rate low.
To allow for the continuum detection of our targets, we have complemented this setup with 2 TDM basebands positioned to cover the rest of the upper sideband.

As the objective of this proposal is the measurement of the total molecular gas content, angular resolution is not critical and most compact configuration is required (i.e., resolution of 1.3"). Our targets are well resolved in the optical and have largest angular scales of <1.5".

To measure the expect CO(4-3) line flux densities of our targets, we use their infrared luminosities (i.e., LIR; derived from MIPS/PACS detections) and assume a LIR/LCO(1-0) ratio of 60 for "normal" galaxies (Genzel et al. 2010 and Daddi et al. 2010), a LCO(4-3)/LCO(1-0) line ratio of 0.4 for "normal" galaxies (Daddi et al. 2014) and a typical CO line width of 300km/s (Tacconi et al. 2013). For P3, this leads to a line peak flux density of 2.02 mJy for our target. For P5, this leads to a line peak flux density of 3.16 mJy for our target.
In the less likely case where our galaxies are in a "starbursting" mode, these line peak flux density estimates would remain unchanged because "normal" and "starbursting" galaxies seems to have the same LCO(J,J-1)/LIR ratio at high-J transitions (J>4; Daddi et al. 2014).
The resquested rms of 0.40 mJy per 75km/s will thus provide us with S/N>5 line peak detections and S/N>10 velocity-integrated line detections (4 channels per line width) of our two targets.
Finally, even though it is not our primary scientific goal, the achieved rms over the aggregate bandwidth will allow us to obtain S/N>4 continuum detections of our targets, as predicted using their (z, LIR, M*) and results from Magnelli et al (2014).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The properties of local galaxies depend on their cosmic environment: star formation (SF) activities are quenched and morphologies change when galaxies enter dense regions. While the mechanisms at the origin of these transitions remain unknown, observations point towards a critical cosmic time, 0.5<z<1, when the influence of large-scaled structures on galaxies become more important. To study these environmental influences, we propose to observe the CO(4-3) line from 14 star-forming galaxies (SFGs) at z~0.73 probing two environments of the COSMOS "Wall": a dense galaxy cluster environment and a sparser galaxy group environment. These observations will provide the essential first step to study environmental effects on the gas properties of galaxies at this critical cosmic epoch. We will investigate if SFGs in dense environments have different amount of fuel (Mgas/(M*+Mgas)) available for SF or different efficiencies for converting molecular gas into stars (SFR/Mgas) compared to that of field SFGs found in the literature. If significant differences are observed, it will favor a nurture origin of the environmental dependencies, while similarities would point toward a nature scenario.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Sussex, University of
Department of Physics, University of Zagreb
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
